awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Boundary Current Control of Upwelling in Southern Drake Passage:  Whither Weddies?
awd_abstract_narration:
Mesoscale processes (~ length scales of up to 100km) are an essential ingredient of the coupling between the waters of the Antarctic margins and the greater Southern Ocean, yet there is a paucity of observations at these space and time scales. The tip of the Antarctic Peninsula is a unique and dynamic environment, and it is of interest to understand how the interaction of large currents with local topographic features and the coupling between physical and biogeochemical processes lead to the transformation of low productivity Antarctic Surface Water (ASW) to high productivity ASW in this region, following admixture with Weddell Sea eddies. By combining high resolution in situ ocean glider observations with remotely-sensed properties of the surface flow, as well as long-term historical data sets, these investigators will infer long-term changes in the frontal structure and mixed layer dynamics of the ACC. The project involves monitoring the fronts in southern Drake Passage over a period of 15 weeks by deploying and piloting a pair of ocean gliders that will collect approximately 1000 profiles of temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, fluorescence and optical backscatter. 

Mesoscale variability in southern Drake Passage influences at least three aspects of Earth?s climate system: the Southern Ocean?s meridional overturning circulation (MOC), air-sea exchange of CO2 and the productivity of the Southern Ocean ecosystems. These processes are of importance to simulating Earth?s climate, and thus to society in general

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the structure and variability of both surface and bottom boundary layers in Drake Passage, Southern Ocean.  This is a unique location as it represents a crossroads of waters entering from the Atlantic and Pacific basins to the north as well as waters from coastal Antarctica to the south.  Mixing in this region, which predominately occurs within boundary layers, has an out-sized impact on setting the density structure and the strength of the global overturning circulation, which is responsible for the long-term storage of heat and carbon in Earth’s climate system.  Observations for this study were collected using ocean gliders, autonomous ocean robotics that permitted continuous, multi-month observational surveys in both summer and winter months in the Southern Ocean’s Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC); this project will provide critical information for designing the role of autonomous vehicles in future Southern Ocean observing systems.

The major results of this study indicated that in the Southern Ocean, both surface and bottom boundary layers are key conduits for the exchange of heat, salt and biologically-relevant tracers such as nutrients and oxygen.  Strong, but narrow frontal currents, found along the continental shelf break in southern Drake Passage, were found to be associated with vigorous vertical motions that transport water with high nutrient and chlorophyll concentrations into deeper offshore waters.  This continuous “pumping” of productive waters likely plays an important in carbon cycling both in Drake Passage and in other regions around Antarctica where boundary currents interact with steeply sloping topography.  In a similar region, we also observed extremely thick bottom mixed layers, typically two to five times larger than common values at mid- and low-latitudes.  We found compelling evidence that these bottom boundary layers give rise to energetic small scale motions that can mix different water masses within the boundary layer.  Estimates of the strength of this mixing, which had previously been assumed to occur largely in the surface ocean in this region, were sufficiently large to suggest that strong currents interacting with topography all along the path of the ACC influences the structure of the global overturning circulation.  This work has implications for interpreting paleo-records of the overturning circulation during different times in Earth’s history.  Finally, we identified abrupt spatial transitions in the properties of the surface boundary layer near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula.  Two regimes, with different properties in the variability of the surface boundary layer, are separated by a deep topographic feature, the Shackleton Fracture Zone, that serves to modify the large-scale background circulation as well as stirring by mesoscale eddies.  Upstream of the fracture zone, the surface mixed layer was observed to be shallow and steady, while downstream it was deep and variable.  These differences are linked to the efficiency of exchange between properties in the surface ocean surface and the ocean interior.  This information will be useful for interpreting data being collected by an autonomous array of bio-Argo floats that are mapping circumpolar biogeochemical properties in the Southern Ocean for the first time (the Southern Ocean Carbon and Climate Observations and Modeling project) .  These results provide additional support for the role of topography in inducing hotspots of eddy kinetic energy, lateral exchange and now potentially air-sea fluxes and biogeochemical cycling.  Ongoing analysis is considering spatial and temporal variations in extreme “ventilation” (exchange between the ocean surface boundary layer an the ocean interior) events near the ACC’s Polar Front.

This project has provided training for three graduate students in physical oceanography, with each student participating in at least one Southern Ocean research cruise.  The students have also gained experience in deploying and piloting ocean gliders and in processing and analyzing the data they collect.  Results from this project have been presented at multiple national and international conferences and have resulted in nine publications to date.
